name: Major Pentatonic Workout
description: Explore the major pentatonic scale across open and movable positions. Bright, country-rock flavored patterns that complement the minor pentatonic.

steps.name: G Major Pentatonic — Open
steps.instructions:
Play the G major pentatonic (G, A, B, D, E) in open position. Ascend from G (3rd fret, 6th string) and descend. One note per beat.

The major pentatonic has a bright, happy sound compared to its minor cousin.
steps.notes: Compare this to Em Pentatonic — same 5 notes (E, G, A, B, D) but G is the tonal center. Context changes everything.

steps.name: E Major Pentatonic — Open
steps.instructions:
Play E major pentatonic (E, F#, G#, B, C#) in open position. Start from open low E. Ascend and descend.

This scale has a distinctly different feel from E minor pentatonic — brighter and more uplifting.
steps.notes: Notice the G# and C# — these are the notes that make it sound 'major' compared to Em pentatonic's G and C natural.

steps.name: C Major Pentatonic — Open
steps.instructions:
Play C major pentatonic (C, D, E, G, A) in open position. Start from C (3rd fret, 5th string). Ascend and descend.

This is the same set of notes as Am pentatonic, but emphasizing C as the root changes the sound completely.
steps.notes: Try starting and ending your runs on C to hear the major tonality. Same notes as Am pentatonic but a totally different vibe.

steps.name: A Major Pentatonic — Position 1
steps.instructions: Play A major pentatonic (A, B, C#, E, F#) in the movable box shape at the 4th–7th fret area. Root is at fret 5 on the 6th string. Ascend and descend.
steps.notes: This movable shape is the major pentatonic equivalent of the minor pentatonic box 1. Learn to see both shapes from the same root.

steps.name: D Major Pentatonic — Position 1
steps.instructions: Play D major pentatonic (D, E, F#, A, B) with the movable shape rooted at fret 10 on the 6th string. Same shape as A major pentatonic, shifted up 5 frets. Ascend and descend.
steps.notes: Common in country, southern rock, and pop. Think of the intro lick from 'Sweet Home Alabama' — that's D and C major pentatonics.

steps.name: C Major Pentatonic — Position 1
steps.instructions: Play C major pentatonic with the movable shape rooted at fret 8 on the 6th string. Compare this higher-position sound to the open position you played earlier. Ascend and descend.
steps.notes: Same notes as the open C major pentatonic, but an octave higher and in a compact box shape. Great for soloing over C or Am.
